lens.book_chapters: Part 1: The Cold Start Problem and Atomic Networks.

crossref_summary: The transcript evidence supports that Roomi-like disappointments are real category behaviors, not just analyst hypotheses. Across both host and guest calls, people repeatedly ask for legitimacy proof, manual vetting, and direct contact before committing; they also describe pricing/search opacity and workflow leakage into text/email. This matches the Cold Start lens: when trust, clarity, and coordination are weak at local decision moments, users do extra manual work and network value fails to compound.

transcript_evidence.speaker: host
transcript_evidence.quote: I keep seeing your postings and I'm just like, I don't know if this guy is legit or what it is.
transcript_evidence.context: Host opens the call from a skepticism posture and questions legitimacy before discussing fit.

transcript_evidence.speaker: host
transcript_evidence.quote: And, you know, I'm just a little very, cause there are so many scams around and I've already been scammed twice.
transcript_evidence.context: Host explicitly reports prior scam exposure, raising trust barriers before transaction details.

transcript_evidence.speaker: guest
transcript_evidence.quote: I have to go and see the space and just to make sure that everything is legit.
transcript_evidence.context: Guest-side decision maker requires trust verification before travel and booking commitment.

transcript_evidence.speaker: guest
transcript_evidence.context: User asks for explicit trust infrastructure rather than relying on listing/profile surface.

validated_disappointments.user_language: Users say "legit," "scams," and "background check"; they do not assume trust from profile/listing alone.
validated_disappointments.framework_reinforcement: This strengthens the Layer 1 claim that raw liquidity is not enough in trust-sensitive matching. Under Cold Start dynamics, weak trust signals reduce effective network density because many nominal matches feel unusable.

transcript_evidence.speaker: guest
transcript_evidence.quote: Has that just been like through texts? Yeah. Um, so he was texting me and saying, Hey, you know, I can't make a fist for another day.
transcript_evidence.context: Rescheduling and commitment changes happen through ad hoc texting instead of a structured in-product flow.

transcript_evidence.speaker: guest
transcript_evidence.quote: the best working is texting me because, uh, I get a lot of emails and sometimes it takes me a little bit to answer to all the miles, but I have answer texts immediately.
transcript_evidence.context: Agent explicitly steers coordination to text due to channel friction, signaling process leakage off structured rails.

transcript_evidence.speaker: host
transcript_evidence.quote: Do we have the opportunity to speak to them or interview them before we several, a week before?
transcript_evidence.context: Host requests manual interview as a pre-commitment safeguard, indicating commitment mechanics are not self-sufficient.

validated_disappointments.user_language: Users describe doing it "through texts" and asking to "interview them" before agreement.
validated_disappointments.framework_reinforcement: This confirms that matching alone does not produce durable outcomes. In Atomic Network terms, value leaks when commitment steps are manual, fragmented, and person-dependent.

transcript_evidence.transcript: Copy of Call with Tom C guest.txt
transcript_evidence.speaker: guest
transcript_evidence.quote: I just wish that sometimes it was a bit more time-to-time price.
transcript_evidence.context: User cannot confidently interpret pricing while searching, increasing cognitive effort and uncertainty.

transcript_evidence.transcript: Copy of Call with Tom C guest.txt
transcript_evidence.speaker: guest
transcript_evidence.quote: I think the main issue I had was that I'm not sure how the content is.
transcript_evidence.context: User signals low confidence in search output quality and relevance during evaluation.

transcript_evidence.speaker: guest
transcript_evidence.quote: there are too many listings for me to remember.
transcript_evidence.context: User and agent rely on manual screenshot exchange because discovery confidence is low.

validated_disappointments.user_language: People say pricing is not clear and that there are too many listings to track reliably.
validated_disappointments.framework_reinforcement: Cold Start framing says the right local participants matter more than raw inventory. These calls show users still doing manual inference about viability, which depresses perceived network utility.

validated_disappointments.disappointment_title: Ghosting Is Normalized by Generic Messaging

transcript_evidence.speaker: guest
transcript_evidence.quote: And then also have the ability to message with Brad.
transcript_evidence.context: Participant asks for structured messaging capability tied to scheduling decisions.

transcript_evidence.speaker: guest
transcript_evidence.quote: we'll be working on, uh, basically just having a way to notify you.
transcript_evidence.context: Need for notification reliability is explicit because current communication timing is fragile.

validated_disappointments.user_language: Users ask for "ability to message" and reliable request notifications rather than informal back-and-forth.
validated_disappointments.framework_reinforcement: This supports the Layer 1 messaging thesis: interaction speed and consistency are core to network value realization, not secondary UX polish.

new_discoveries.title: Pre-Commitment Authenticity Check Becomes Mandatory User Labor

transcript_evidence.speaker: guest
transcript_evidence.quote: I have to go and see the space and just to make sure that everything is legit.
transcript_evidence.context: User requires an extra verification step before booking.

transcript_evidence.speaker: host
transcript_evidence.quote: And I also will send you my LinkedIn profile so you could see me there as well.
transcript_evidence.context: Trust must be bootstrapped manually through off-platform identity proof.

new_discoveries.relates_to_competitor: Roomi operates in the same trust-sensitive roommate category; when platform-native trust is insufficient, users add manual authenticity checks before commitment.
new_discoveries.framework_analysis: In Cold Start terms, this is anti-network friction: every extra verification step lowers conversion velocity and can keep local networks below tipping density.

new_discoveries.title: Search + Pricing Ambiguity Pushes Users Into Assisted, Manual Discovery

transcript_evidence.transcript: Copy of Call with Tom C guest.txt
transcript_evidence.speaker: guest
transcript_evidence.quote: I just wish that sometimes it was a bit more time-to-time price.
transcript_evidence.context: User expects transparent pricing while browsing but cannot confidently read it.

transcript_evidence.transcript: Copy of Call with Tom C guest.txt
transcript_evidence.speaker: guest
transcript_evidence.quote: I think the main issue I had was that I'm not sure how the content is.
transcript_evidence.context: User reports weak confidence in search result reliability.

transcript_evidence.speaker: guest
transcript_evidence.quote: there are too many listings for me to remember.
transcript_evidence.context: Decision process shifts to screenshots, agent memory, and manual follow-up.

new_discoveries.relates_to_competitor: For Roomi, this implies that fast browsing alone is insufficient if users still cannot forecast matchability and true cost from the interface.
new_discoveries.framework_analysis: Atomic networks win when users quickly find relevant participants and can act. Ambiguity forces extra steps, reducing interaction throughput and slowing local network compounding.

library_connections.connection: works-004 addresses the trust handoff by explicitly bridging human trust to digital trust, which maps to repeated user requests for legitimacy proof.
works-003 focuses on matching conversational speed in-platform; this directly targets the current workaround of handling reschedules and negotiations in text/email.
works-006 translates user mental models into platform models, reducing manual interpretation burden in search/pricing decisions.
communicates-002 proposes single-sum financial clarity; transcript evidence shows users explicitly struggling with pricing transparency during discovery.

transcripts_with_matches: Copy of Call with Tom C guest.txt
